bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, September 12, 1940

div1.p: [Philip Hench] hopes that his brother, Atcheson, can meet Moran. [Philip Hench] also writes about his honorary degree from Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Atcheson Laughlin Hench, September 12, 1940
div1.p:
I think you have heard me talk about Mr. Moran. I hope for my
sake that you can meet him when he comes to Charlottesville. He is a very pleasant
Irishman and of course has a secure place (though rather obscure) in medical history,
as one of the two who first volunteered to Reed to get experimental yellow fever.
The part which Robert Montgomery took in the motion picture version of “Yellow Jack”
was Mr. Moran in life. You remember I visited him in Havana. His wife is very
pleasant but speaks very little English, being a Spaniard. He will probably be
taken care of largely by the medical men but I do hope that you can meet him and
make yourself known.

You will be interested to know that I am to receive a degree on
the occasion of the dedication of the Lazear Memorial. As you know, I am giving
an address and I guess they thought they had better give me a degree! Last Spring
when I heard of the Lafayette degree, I wrote Hutch a few days later, thanking him
most heartily for the part I assumed he had played in getting me this degree.
I didn't know he had but suspect strongly that he had. He said he hadn't had
anything to do about it, and in a way was very sorry about it, as the week before,
his Board of Trustees had authorized my receiving an honorary degree at W. and J.
Apparently, one of Father's friends nominated me to the trustees of W. and J. three
or four years ago. The nomination was seconded recently by someone else. Hutch
didn't tell me who. Hutch assures me that he didn't nominate me himself, but was
just waiting for some appropriate occasion to carry out the suggestion, and this
is it. Naturally, I am very delighted, but don't feel that I deserve one, much
less two such honors. The affair is Friday, October 25.

By the way, how did your pictures of yourself and me turn out:
You never sent me any. Mary Showalter was delighted to have the ones you sent her.
